verses.text: There was a famine in the days of David for three years, year after year. So David sought the face of the LORD. The LORD said, 'It is because of Saul and his bloodguilt, because he put the Gibeonites to death.'
verses.comment: The famine is interpreted as a divine response to Saul's violence against the Gibeonites, highlighting corporate responsibility and the serious consequences of violating oaths (cf. Josh. 9).

verses.text: So the king called the Gibeonites and spoke to them. (Now the Gibeonites were not of the children of Israel, but of the remnant of the Amorites. Although the Israelites had sworn to spare them, Saul had tried to strike them down in his zeal for the people of Israel and Judah.)
verses.comment: This verse sets the background—that the Gibeonites, spared by oath, were unjustly attacked by Saul. Keeping sworn covenants is a recurring biblical theme.

verses.text: David said to the Gibeonites, 'What shall I do for you? How shall I make atonement, that you may bless the inheritance of the LORD?'
verses.comment: The request for atonement shows David acting as mediator, a kingly priestly role foreshadowing Christ’s mediation (cf. Lev. 16; Heb. 9:15).

verses.text: The Gibeonites said to him, 'It is not a matter of silver or gold between us and Saul or his house; neither is it for us to put any man to death in Israel.' And he said, 'What do you say I shall do for you?'
verses.comment: The Gibeonites reject monetary compensation, seeking true justice. This reflects God's justice that cannot be bought—atonement is more than mere payment.

verses.text: They said to the king, 'The man who consumed us and planned to destroy us, so that we should have no place in all the territory of Israel,
verses.comment: The Gibeonites recall Saul’s attempt at extermination, underscoring the severity of his offense.

verses.text: let seven men of his sons be given to us, so that we may hang them before the LORD at Gibeah of Saul, the chosen of the LORD.' And the king said, 'I will give them.'
verses.comment: The execution 'before the LORD' recalls the gravity of public atonement. Seven symbolizes fullness or completion. This event prefigures the concept of substitutionary atonement (cf. Heb. 9:22), though imperfect compared to Christ’s sacrifice.

verses.text: But the king spared Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan the son of Saul, because of the oath of the LORD that was between them, between David and Jonathan the son of Saul.
verses.comment: David honors his personal covenant with Jonathan, upholding the sanctity of oaths even amid severe judgment.

verses.text: So the king took the two sons of Rizpah the daughter of Aiah, whom she bore to Saul, Armoni and Mephibosheth, and the five sons of Merab the daughter of Saul, whom she bore to Adriel the son of Barzillai the Meholathite.
verses.comment: Some manuscripts read 'Michal' instead of 'Merab'. The selection retains fairness to Saul’s line except for David’s covenant-protected Mephibosheth.

verses.text: He delivered them into the hands of the Gibeonites, and they hanged them on the mountain before the LORD. All seven of them fell together; they were put to death in the days of harvest, at the beginning of barley harvest.
verses.comment: Public execution during harvest echoes the seriousness of national sin—a warning not to transgress God's covenants.

verses.text: Rizpah the daughter of Aiah took sackcloth and spread it for herself on the rock, from the beginning of harvest until the rain fell from the heavens on the bodies. She did not allow the birds of the air to settle on them by day, or the beasts of the field by night.
verses.comment: Rizpah’s vigil demonstrates steadfast love and motherly intercession—shadows of perpetual devotion and the role of intercession for the dead.

verses.text: When it was told David what Rizpah the daughter of Aiah, the concubine of Saul, had done,
verses.comment: Her action moves David, evidencing how persistent devotion can influence events even in the context of royal decree.

verses.text: David went and took the bones of Saul and the bones of Jonathan his son from the men of Jabesh-gilead, who had stolen them from the public square of Beth-shan, where the Philistines had hung them, on the day the Philistines killed Saul on Gilboa.
verses.comment: Proper burial honors are significant for closure, justice, and reconciliation—prefiguring respect for the bodies of the deceased (cf. 1Sam. 31).

verses.text: He brought up from there the bones of Saul and the bones of Jonathan his son, and they gathered the bones of those who had been hanged.
verses.comment: The physical gathering of bones for burial underscores the value of honoring the dead.

verses.text: They buried the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son in the land of Benjamin, in Zela, in the tomb of Kish his father. They did all that the king commanded, and after that God responded to the plea for the land.
verses.comment: Proper burial and obedience lead to restoration. The response to the plea foreshadows God’s mercy when justice is met, paralleling the effects of true repentance and restitution.

verses.text: Once again there was war between the Philistines and Israel. David went down, and his servants with him, and they fought against the Philistines. David grew weary.
verses.comment: David’s vulnerability as king is on display. Even chosen leaders experience weakness and need the support of others.

verses.text: Ishbi-benob, one of the descendants of the giants, whose bronze spear weighed three hundred shekels, and who was armed with a new sword, thought to kill David.
verses.comment: The continuing threat of giants echoes the earlier battles (cf. Goliath); David as a type of Christ faces the enemies of God’s people.

verses.text: But Abishai the son of Zeruiah came to his aid and struck the Philistine and killed him. Then David’s men swore to him, 'You shall no longer go out with us to battle, so that you do not extinguish the lamp of Israel.'
verses.comment: David is called the 'lamp of Israel,' symbolizing leadership and continuity, ultimately pointing toward the light brought by Christ (cf. John 1:9).

verses.text: After this, there was again war with the Philistines at Gob. Then Sibbecai the Hushathite struck down Saph, who was one of the descendants of the giants.
verses.comment: David’s valiant men share in his victories, foreshadowing how Christ shares victory with those united to him.

verses.text: There was again war with the Philistines at Gob. Elhanan the son of Jaare-oregim the Bethlehemite struck down Goliath the Gittite, the shaft of whose spear was like a weaver's beam.
verses.comment: Some manuscripts say Elhanan killed the brother of Goliath, which harmonizes chronologically. The victory emphasizes the defeat of apparent invincible enemies by faith.

verses.text: And there was again war at Gath, where there was a man of great stature, who had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot, twenty-four in number, and he also was descended from the giants.
verses.comment: The physical description emphasizes the abnormal threat and how even great natural obstacles are overcome by God’s people.

verses.text: And when he taunted Israel, Jonathan the son of Shimei, David’s brother, struck him down.
verses.comment: A member of David’s family wins the victory, signifying that the king’s house shares in the fight against evil. This prefigures the spiritual warfare faced by all the faithful.

verses.text: These four were descended from the giants in Gath, and they fell by the hand of David and by the hand of his servants.
verses.comment: The passage concludes with the defeat of Israel’s enemies through David and his followers, hinting at the future universal kingship of the Messiah (cf. Ps. 2).
